poem:
Bridget Alone Again  
  
A page turns, air crisp, in morning light—  
Bridget stands, a pierced heart, children clinging tight.  
Mark's shadow, soft yet stark, fades—  
life's humors and heavy frames,  
woven by unseen hands.  
Morning's sun spills over a cluttered table,  
maybe marmalade and crumbs,  
an ordinary world's quiet courage.
